status_message_cleaned: Do you remember me? I am a Common Loon and the mascot of the Canadian Wildlife Service at Environment and Climate Change Canada. Some time ago, I asked to be named, and you suggested lots of great ones. I chose “Kwimu.” It means “spirit bird” in many Indigenous languages. Since the name “Tuuli” was also very popular, I decided to give this name to the chick that I carry on my back. Tuuli means loon in Inuktitut. Thanks for giving me a name!

status_message_cleaned: The Peary Caribou, which lives in the high Arctic islands of Nunavut and Northwest Territories, is listed as endangered under the Species at Risk Act. Micheline, a wildlife scientist at Parks Canada, and her team combine Indigenous knowledge and innovative research techniques to study changes in caribou behaviour and diet. status_message_cleaned: Air pollution is one of the most significant environmental problems affecting our health. It adversely affects our lakes and oceans, and causes acid rain and smog. Some of the air pollution in Canada comes from outside the country. That’s why Canada just ratified the Gothenburg Protocol, an international agreement to reduce air pollutants. Under the Protocol, Canada will continue taking action on air pollution by reducing these dangerous emissions. We’re taking action to provide Canadians with clean air and a healthier environment.

status_message_cleaned: Today, Minister Jim Carr of Natural Resources Canada announced the creation of a Generation Energy Council to provide recommendations on how Canada can prepare for the reliable, affordable, low-carbon economy of the future. The Council will assemble takeaways from both the forum and the six-month engagement that asked Canadians from across the country what their energy future looked like. Transforming how our society makes, moves and uses energy will redefine Canada’s energy future, resulting in good, middle-class jobs and a sustainable environment for future generations. Learn more:

status_message_cleaned: Did you know that two science weather supersites have been built in Iqaluit and Whitehorse? The weather information required in the North differs from what the population uses in the rest of Canada. For example, blowing snow and ice-fog are critical information for northern communities; more relevant than the temperature and humidity. Environment and Climate Change Canada’s Weather Science team will use the data from the supersites to better understand and support weather forecasts that are more relevant to the needs of the people living in the North.

status_message_cleaned: The Great Lakes region is part of our physical and cultural heritage. We depend on them for drinking water, recreation, transportation, power and economic opportunities. Yet, the demands of a large population in this region have taken their toll over time. The impacts of industrialization, climate change, invasive species and toxic contaminants, among other pressures, are evident. status_message_cleaned: Quiz time for kids: Oceans, forests and wetlands that take carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere are called? - Carbon footprint - Carbon sinks - Carbon magic Encourage your children and students to learn about climate science by playing the Climate Science Brain Buster Quiz on the Climate Kids website. ANSWER: Oceans, forests and wetlands that take carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere are called carbon sinks. Carbon sinks such as oceans, forests and wetlands remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere by absorbing it like a sponge. We can help reduce effects of climate change by protecting natural ecosystems that are carbon sinks.

status_message_cleaned: Canada’s Minister of Environment and Climate Change, Catherine McKenna, is hosting an international meeting this week in Montreal focused, in part, on implementing one of the biggest, single, global climate actions ever taken: phasing down hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs). We all use HFCs in things like our fridges and air conditioners and they do a great job of cooling us down. Unfortunately, they also warm the planet. Delegates at the Montreal Protocol meeting are working to implement the Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol which calls for a global HFC phase down. Countries adopted the Amendment last year and Canada recently became one of the first countries to ratify it. Canada is taking huge steps towards a clean future for our children and grandchildren, and as part of this, urges other countries to ratify the Kigali Amendment.

status_message_cleaned: Congratulations to Dr. Bell and the team from Memorial University of Newfoundland who created SmartICE. At the United Nations Climate Conference COP23, they received the UN Climate Solutions Awards for their outstanding work adapting to climate change. They developed a tool that helps Indigenous Peoples adapt to thinning sea-ice. The tool provides information to aid in the planning of safe routes on the ice, which helps to reduce travel risks. SmartICE’s work underlines how global climate action is accelerating two years after the Paris Agreement was universally adopted.

status_message_cleaned: Canadian Solar was founded in in Guelph, Ontario, and is one of the three biggest solar companies in the world by revenue. There are over ,700 employees working in countries on six continents, making it a global leader among clean technology companies. In June , Ert Development Canada (EDC) announced $91 million in financing to Canadian Solar to aid in the construction of the Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum Solar Park in Dubai, which when completed, will be the most powerful solar power plant in the world. In addition to the project being groundbreaking in size, Canadian Solar is using innovative practices to maximize efficiency as well. The park will use tilting panels to track the sun, rather than standard conventional solar power arrays.

Environment and Climate Change Canada is partnering with the Nature Conservancy of Canada through the Natural Areas Conservation Program to protect this unique environment.

status_message_cleaned: Micheline’s research focuses on caribou ecology and genetics in different regions of the country and internationally. She uses genetic methods to assess how landscape features affect the distribution, movement and abundance of caribou. Micheline collaborates with Indigenous organizations and communities to bring the best knowledge to inform conservation issues.

status_message_cleaned: Last week was the start of the hunting season in the Quebec Region. On September , through a joint operation between Environment and Climate Change Canada’s Wildlife Enforcement Branch and the Ministère des Forêts, de la Faune et des Parcs du Québec (French only), hunters suspected of killing migratory birds illegally and violating laws and regulations surrounding the practice of this activity were intercepted. In total, ducks were seized. An investigation is currently underway to lay charges against the hunters involved. Before you go hunting, find out about the migratory bird hunting regulations for your area. Migratory birds are protected under the Migratory Birds Convention Act, , but hunting of certain species, such as ducks and geese, is allowed during specific periods and in specific areas across Canada. To learn more about these regulations:

status_message_cleaned: In , NASA invited scientific groups from around the world to submit proposals to study lunar material from the Apollo mission. The Geological Survey of Canada (GSC) submitted several proposals, and all were accepted! The GSC received the moon rocks and put them on display to the public. The collection included rock fragments, polished thin sections and soil. There was strong public interest, and long line-ups snaked their way into the GSC’s headquarters at Booth Street! If you live near Dartmouth, Nova Scotia, come visit Booth at the Bio E this weekend and see how everyday electronics depend on earth’s rare metals.

status_message_cleaned: This weekend, Canada and the world celebrated the th anniversary of the Montreal Protocol. The Montreal Protocol is a historic international agreement that has eliminated over % of substances that were thinning the earth’s ozone layer. Like the Paris Agreement, it shows the amazing things we can accomplish when countries work together on a common goal. It’s a reminder of what the world needs to continue to do to address the global threat of climate change.

status_message_cleaned: We are creating a souvenir album celebrating years of bird conservation in Canada. Share with us your bird anecdotes or thoughts on birds today! The album will contain testimonials and photos of people. status_message_cleaned: Canadians want to live in clean and healthy communities. The Government of Canada is working to meet its federal sustainable development goals on clean energy, clean growth, and safe and healthy communities. They support the agenda’s “Good Health and Well-Being” , “Affordable and Clean Energy”, “Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure”, and “Responsible Consumption and Production” goals. status_message_cleaned: Last week was the first deadline to apply for funding through the Environmental Damages Fund (EDF). There’s still more available! If you’re in Northern Québec or Labrador regions, EDF still has $3.45M in funding available until October . A Québec company was ordered to pay $7.5M after pleading guilty to charges under the Fisheries Act. This is the largest penalty ever given for an environmental infraction. Environment and Climate Change Canada puts a lot of consideration into where the funds go. Of that $7.5M, $6.83 was directed to EDF and today $3.45 is available to fund projects that will benefit the affected area. For more information about this Fund and to find out if your project qualifies for funding, click here:

status_message_cleaned: Atlantic Canada is currently seeing an outbreak of Trichomonosis. It is a bird parasite that affects the upper digestive tract of birds, limiting their ability to swallow and keep their food down. Although bird feeders and baths make it easier for us to watch birds in their natural habitat, they can be harmful during an outbreak. You can help slow down the spread of Trichomonosis by removing bird feeders and baths and following these simple steps: BIRD FEEDERS AND BATHS ) Take down your bird feeders and bird baths. During the summer, there is enough natural food available, so there is no need to worry. ) Wash them thoroughly with a weak bleach solution (5% sodium hypochlorite). ) Dispose of any wet or eed feed left around your bird feeders and baths. ) Refrain from putting them back in your yard until the cooler temperatures in the Fall. For more information on Trichomonosis: U9

status_message_cleaned: With a watershed that spans four provinces and four states, Lake Winnipeg is Canada’s sixth largest lake and an important resource for Canadians. Lake Winnipeg is also culturally, socially and economically significant to the health of Indigenous peoples and their communities. It is also important to the Canadian economy, generating millions of dollars of revenue in the hydroelectric, recreation and commercial freshwater fishing industries. That’s why the Government of Canada is investing $25.7 million for the Lake Winnipeg Basin Program. The Program will include efforts to reduce nutrients and improve water quality, and engaging Indigenous partners and collaborators at all levels in Canada and U.S. for strong action to protect shared waters of Lake Winnipeg.

status_message_cleaned: Grand Manan Island Migratory Bird Sanctuary in New Brunswick is home to dozens of species of songbirds, shorebirds, and migratory waterfowl. status_message_cleaned: On March , , at :06 a.m. local time, a meteor flashed through the sky near Bruderheim, Alberta. The sound of its impact hitting Earth was audible over ,000 square kilometres. Weighing in at over kilograms, the Bruderheim Meteorite still holds the title of Canada’s largest discovered meteorite. And at roughly billion years old, it’s fair to say it’s a gem in our National Meteorite Collection. !

status_message_cleaned: Ammonites are fossils of an unusual marine cephalopod invertebrates that went extinct about million years ago. Due to their distinct characteristics, paleontologists from around the world study, classify and use them as indicators of geological time periods. Today, different species have been found around the Pacific Rim, in Japan, Russia, Alaska, British Columbia and California. Their relatives — squid, octopus and nautilus — still live in today’s oceans.

status_message_cleaned: Pointe-au-Père National Wildlife Area is one of the best shorebird-watching sites in Quebec. In the spring, flocks of Least Sandpipers congregate at the site, while Great Blue Heron feed in the marshes in the company of Black-crowned Night-herons and large communities of Brants. In the summer, American Black Ducks, Mallards, Northern Pintails and Green-winged Teals raise their young and feed on the plentiful invertebrates in the brackish ponds. During the fall migration, Red-throated Loon and Common Loon, and large numbers of Canada Geese, are observed. Large communities of Sanderlings and Semipalmated Sandpipers also use the area, along with the White-rumped Sandpiper.

status_message_cleaned: Fact or fiction? A tree is a safe hiding place from lightning. When thunder roars GO, INDOORS! Fiction: No, in fact standing under a tree is one of the most dangerous places to be during a thunderstorm. Lightning can strike a tree and the current can travel down the trunk and exit two ways: it can side flash from mid-trunk and jump out and hit you. Or, the lightning can flow out through the roots and you can be hit by ground current. If you are in a forested area during a storm, stay on the trail, not near a tree, and keep everyone a few metres apart from each other. 9D

status_message_cleaned: A new restriction temporarily prohibits the import of all species of salamanders, newts and mudpuppies, for one-year, unless authorized by a permit issued by Environment and Climate Change Canada. A deadly disease-causing fungus, suspected to have spread from Asia via the pet trade, has been devastating salamander populations in Europe. Wild salamanders play a vital role in Canada’s ecosystems as part of the food web and in nutrient and carbon cycling. If the fungus enters Canadian ecosystems, the impacts on our native salamanders could be devastating.

status_message_cleaned: years ago, the UV Index was launched by Environment and Climate Change Canada’s scientists. Two years later, it was adopted by the World Health Organization and the United Nations Environment Program, and it is now used internationally. The UV Index is a measure of the strength of the sun’s UV rays. It is based on the thickness of the ozone layer in the upper atmosphere, the angle of the sun above the horizon and the amount of cloud cover. As the UV increases, the sun’s rays can do more harm to your skin, eyes and immune system. Congratulations to Environment and Climate Change Canada’s scientists for developing such a useful tool!

Apply to an EcoAction Community Funding Program to improve your local environment. Read these success stories and get inspired to take action in your own community! Are you a member of an Indigenous organizations or community? status_message_cleaned: Some Canadian companies, from Loblaws, to Canadian Tire, to the five big banks, have come out strongly in support of a price on pollution. Canadian companies are choosing cleaner options as they produce and sell their products. They are making their operations more efficient. And they are putting bold ideas into action and creating good-paying middle-class jobs and opportunities in the process. Countries from China to Chile to those in the European Union, and American states like Oregon and California – the sixth largest economy in the world – are all pricing carbon pollution. These major economies are putting a price on carbon pollution because it works, and because it is the most effective way to reach our emissions reductions goals while growing strong economies.

status_message_cleaned: Lake Erie needs your help! Harmful and nuisance algal blooms are hurting Lake Erie’s environment and economy, and present risks to human health. But a healthier lake is possible. Canadians have until May to comment on a draft action plan to help reduce the amount of phosphorus – a key factor causing algae – from entering the lake. Your comments and ideas will help build a final Plan with specific actions to help restore water quality in Lake Erie. Public meetings are taking place on May and in the Lake Erie basin. Can’t make it in person? Share your ideas online!

status_message_cleaned: The towering cliffs overlooking Big Trout Bay, on the north shore of Lake Superior near the U.S.-Canada border, are home to the peregrine falcon. This majestic bird, once nearly extinct in southern Canada, is assessed as special concern by the Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada. The Government of Canada is investing $2.3 million to help Nature Conservancy of Canada / Conservation de la nature Canada to protect over ,000 pristine hectares around Big Trout Bay, which includes important breeding habitat for the peregrine falcon.

status_message_cleaned: Canada is committed to investing in programs that protect the land, water and air. has made key investments in Indigenous Guardians Program, a program that employs as the "eyes on the ground" in Indigenous territories. They monitor ecological health, maintain cultural sites and protect sensitive areas and species. They play a vital role in creating land-use and marine-use plans. And they promote intergenerational sharing of Indigenous knowledge—helping train the next generation of educators, ministers and nation builders.

status_message_cleaned: Let’s celebrate today! It marks the launch of a new edition of the World Meteorological Organization's International Cloud Atlas. Clouds are one of the key uncertainties in the study of climate change: we need to better understand how clouds affect the climate and how a changing climate will affect clouds. The new Atlas contains hundreds of images of clouds, including a few newly classified cloud types. It also features other meteorological phenomena such as rainbows, halos, snow devils and hailstones. status_message_cleaned: While most Canadians only hear about the National Energy Board’s involvement at the beginning of projects, we actually regulate Canada’s federal energy infrastructure throughout its entire life cycle. We do not simply make a decision on a project and walk away. When approved projects are being built and operated, we inspect and audit them. When a pipeline has reached the end of its usefulness, we hold a hearing to review abandonment applications to ensure that it is abandoned in a safe and environmentally responsible manner.

status_message_cleaned: – June , – is a chance to celebrate Canada’s biodiversity! Biodiversity – the life forms we eerience all around us, yet know remarkably little about. This wide array of ecosystems, ecological processes, species and genes is essential to our existence. Even as scientists discover new species (estimates suggest millions remain unknown), it is clear that our biodiversity is under threat – from competing land uses, pollution, population growth and human activities. Environment and Climate Change Canada and its partners work to conserve our biodiversity. Find out what we are doing to address this daunting global challenge.

status_message_cleaned: Did you know for more than years, Canada and the United States have conducted a large-scale banding program on the Canadian Prairies? Each August, biologists from Canadian Wildlife Service and U.S. Fish and Wildlife work together to band thousands of birds prior to their annual migration as part of the Western Canada Cooperative Waterfowl Banding Program. Last Mountain Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary is one of sites where the banding takes place. Ducks flying south from Canada to the U.S. and beyond are tracked through reports to the Canadian Wildlife Service Bird Banding Office and the U.S. Geological Survey. Reports of banded bird encounters help document their longevity, movements and sources of mortality. This data helps scientists better understand migratory birds, determine appropriate regulations and ultimately contribute to their survival.

status_message_cleaned: Current Ecological Gifts stretch across every region of southern Canada and make a big contribution to creating a network of protected areas! These donations help to protect Canada’s natural heritage for future generations. The Kofman Moose Bay Ecological Gift in the O’Donnell Point Natural Area in the Georgian Bay Littoral UNESCO Biosphere Reserve is a great example! The area is home to five reptilian species at risk. By accepting donations of ecologically sensitive land, the Georgian Bay Land Trust helps to protect rare habitats and conserve Canada’s biodiversity.

status_message_cleaned: Dive into Canada’s newest Marine Protected Area: the Hecate Strait and Queen Charlotte Sound Glass Sponge Reefs. In the deep, cold waters of Hecate Strait and Queen Charlotte Sound, British Columbia, Canada, beautiful creatures – glass sponges – create a vibrant and unique reef ecosystem. This Marine Protected Area is helping to safeguard the globally unique and important aquatic environment that provides key habitats for marine wildlife.

status_message_cleaned: Do you want to know more about air pollutants in your province? We just released Canada’s Air Pollutant Emission Inventory (APEI). It’s a comprehensive inventory of emissions of air pollutants from different emissions sources, at the national, provincial and territorial levels. Why should you care? Because air pollution can hurt your health by irritating the lungs, reducing lung function, and increasing susceptibility to allergens in people with asthma. Air pollution also hurts the environment by reducing the growth and productivity of some crops and injuring flowers, shrubs and forests. And economically, air pollution hurts us by increasing health care costs, missed days of work and reduced worker productivity, costing the Canadian economy billions of dollars per year.

status_message_cleaned: Looking for a way to contribute to conservation? Citizen scientists play an important role in many of our monitoring programs and provide biologists with invaluable information. While on a recent vacation to Cuba, nature photographer and citizen scientist, Alan Chaplin, did not know the Piping Plover he was snapping photos of was extraordinary. He reported the band only to discover that this bird had outlived its average lifespan by more than times! The -year old plover was spotted near the same location our biologists banded it in . It bred on Cavendish Beach in Prince Edward Island National Park in the early s but had not been reported in over a decade. This resight is extremely useful for our scientists in understanding this at-risk species. Piping Plover continue to be marked in Canada, now with uniquely coded leg flags. For information on how to report a banded Piping Plover:

status_message_cleaned: Shirley is an applied ecology technician at Environment and Climate Change Canada. Her work involves planning and conducting several types of aerial waterfowl surveys, including monitoring breeding pairs in the spring, Barrow’s Goldeneye in winter and the Common Eider at various times of year. She also takes part in duck and goose banding operations, which gives her a chance to travel to various locations in Quebec. Her work involves flying in helicopters at low altitudes with a lot of changes in direction (not for the queasy!). What she loves about her job is the combination of field and office work. Her advice to women who are interested: take the time to find a career where you can combine your interests, abilities and values.

status_message_cleaned: Happy ! Canadian wetlands provide enormous benefits to people by protecting against floods, improving water quality and water supply, controlling erosion and supporting a variety of recreational activities. Although the importance of wetlands is being recognized more and more; many of Canada’s wetlands in settled areas have been lost, and Canada continues to lose these important habitats – both naturally and because of human-related activities. The National Wetland Conservation Fund (NWCF) supports organizations and communities across Canada to participate actively in the restoration and enhancement of degraded wetlands. For example, an NWCF project led by Ducks Unlimited Canada enhanced hectares of wetland habitat throughout N.B., N.S. and P.E.I. Find out more about NWCF:

status_message_cleaned: Over the past five decades, the area covered by sea ice in Canada's Arctic has been decreasing at an unprecedented rate. This shrinking has an effect on the safety of northerners who use the ice as transportation routes or platforms for hunting and fishing. Wildlife, such as polar bears that depend on the ice for their survival, is also affected as their food supply and habitat diminish. Take some time to learn more about the impacts of a changing climate on Canada's sea ice.

status_message_cleaned: Cool tech alert! Environment and Climate Change Canada’s climate scientists mapped snow depth transects using self-recording GPS depth probes shown here. They each have backpacks with rechargeable batteries linked to a data-logger and a GPS antenna to record depth probe readings. These on-the-ground measurements help scientists better understand the characteristics of tundra snow. The data collected was used to refine computer models used to predict climate change. For reference: C. Derksen, P. Toose, A. Rees, L. Wang, M. English, A. Walker, M. Sturm, Development of a tundra-specific snow water equivalent retrieval algorithm for satellite passive microwave data, Remote Sensing of Environment, Volume , Issue , August , Pages -1709.

status_message_cleaned: Oak Lake and Plum Lake lie at the heart of an extensive system of wetlands in southwestern Manitoba near Brandon. Each year, tens of thousands of waterbirds -- including Franklin's Gull, Snow Goose and Tundra Swan -- descend on the lakes as part of their annual migration cycle. Environment and Climate Change Canada is partnering with Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect an additional hectares of wetlands habitat in the Oak Lake and Plum Lake area. This initiative demonstrates our ongoing commitment to the North American Waterfowl Management Plan, which was signed by the governments of Canada and the United States in and later by Mexico in . c

status_message_cleaned: Randle Reef is an area of contaminated sediment located in Hamilton Harbour approximately hectares in size. It contains ,000 cubic metres of contaminated sediment at the bottom of the harbour — a volume that would fill a major hockey arena three times over. The clean-up project will cost $138.9 million and will be completed in . Environment and Climate Change Canada and the Ontario Ministry of the Environment and Climate Change have each committed $46.3 million, with the final third of funding coming from the City of Hamilton, the City of Burlington, Halton Region, the Hamilton Port Authority and U.S. Steel Canada. Check us out on YouTube — search word “Randle Reef” and online at .

Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Environment and Climate Change Minister, Catherine McKenna will attend a meeting with First Nations, Inuit, and Métis leaders, and later the First Minister’s Meeting with the Premiers. This plan will create a low-carbon, clean growth and inclusive Canadian economy.

status_message_cleaned: The proposed designation of Scott Islands as the first marine National Wildlife Area will complement the five protected islands that make up the Scott Islands archipelago. Located off the northwest tip of Vancouver Island, British Columbia, the Scott Islands support the highest concentration of breeding seabirds in the Canadian Pacific. This includes: • percent of Canada’s Tufted Puffins • percent of Pacific Canada’s Common Murre • percent of the world’s Cassin’s Auklets • percent of the global population of Rhinoceros Auklet Find out more:

status_message_cleaned: Canadians have generously donated more than ,200 ecological gifts, protecting over ,000 hectares of land between -2016. In addition to the peace of mind that comes with preserving these lands for future generations, donors received significant income tax benefits. Many of these pieces of land contain areas designated as being of national or provincial significance, and are home to some of Canada’s species at risk. For example, the MacPhail family donated hectares of mature Wapane’kati or Acadian forest in Elmwood, PEI to Island Nature Trust to ensure the land is conserved! They will make sure that habitat is protected for local song birds, small mammals, amphibians and other wildlife. For more information about how to donate land that is important to you and our environment:

status_message_cleaned: When it comes to connecting with nature, it also means taking care of it! Science shows that triclosan, a chemical used as an antimicrobial ingredient, can cause harm to aquatic organisms, like plants and fish. The harm happens when products that contain this substance are washed down household drains and then released into water. Get the scoop on what the Government of Canada is doing to address this issue!

status_message_cleaned: Each year, thousands of shorebirds and waterfowl can be seen on the beaches and lagoons of Miscou Island, off the coast of New Brunswick, during their fall migration. The Government of Canada is pleased to partner with Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect an additional hectares of this ecologically-sensitive wetlands habitat. By protecting the lands from development, this area will continue to serve as an important refuge for migratory birds such as the Piping Plover, listed as endangered under the Species at Risk Act. Conserving coastal lands like these also benefits local communities by helping to mitigate the impacts of storms and rising sea levels associated with climate change.

status_message_cleaned: Happy ! Local, Indigenous, recreational and commercial fisheries provide important economic and social benefits to Canadians. Canada has unparalleled ocean resources and an abundance of pristine lakes and rivers across the country. Managing our fisheries sustainably helps keep our waters healthy. status_message_cleaned: The magnificent Ferruginous Hawk, with a wingspan that can reach m, is one of the largest species of hawks. Once found widely across the prairie provinces, its population has declined by almost two-thirds since due largely to habitat loss! Today, this majestic bird is listed as threatened under the Species at Risk Act. To help give ferruginous hawks and other wildlife species a chance to thrive, Environment and Climate Change Canada is partnering with Nature Conservancy of Canada to conserve more than ,200 hectares of prairie grassland in Alberta's Porcupine Hills region. This land will be protected in perpetuity under the Government of Canada’s Ecological Gifts Program.

status_message_cleaned: Did you know that a significant number of toiletries such as scrubs and toothpastes are known to contain thousands of minuscule pieces of plastic called microbeads? These end up in our waterways and ultimately in the marine food chain. Today, we’re taking another important step to phase out the use of microbeads and protect the long-term health of our environment. Let’s keep Canada’s lakes and rivers clean! We want to hear from you during the -day consultation period on these proposed Microbeads in Toiletries Regulations. Submit your comments to the following e-mail address: ec.produits-products.ec.ca, by January , .

Kathy studies the ecology and life history of alpine and arctic songbirds and grouse across different elevations. Her research program has led to about scientific papers, changes in forest operational practices and management recommendations for endangered species. Kathy received the Ian McTaggart Cowan Lifetime achievement award in which recognizes individuals who have made outstanding contributions to the understanding, conservation and/or management of wildlife in Canada over their career.

status_message_cleaned: Migratory birds are a vital part of Canada’s environment, eating insects, dispersing seeds and pollinating plants. Their natural beauty and seasonal migrations are integral to Canada’s heritage. Nature NB recently received $125,000 through the Environmental Damages Fund‒funding that came from a court penalty associated with a situation where thousands of migratory birds were killed. The project will research migratory bird migration and raise public awareness about the importance of migratory birds in southern New Brunswick.

status_message_cleaned: The St. Lawrence River is a complex ecosystem with many different habitats that are home to many different plants, fish and animals. Wastewater and agricultural runoff release phosphorus and nitrogen into the river causing aquatic plants to thrive in what are called “algae blooms”. These blooms reduce oxygen available for fish and other aquatic animals. The more often phosphorus and nitrogen levels exceed guidelines, the greater the risk to the river's ecosystem health. Check out the current status of the St. Lawrence in our environmental indicators release!

status_message_cleaned: In partnership with Nature Conservancy of Canada / Conservation de la nature Canada, the Government of Canada is investing more than $2 million through the Natural Areas Conservation Program to support the protection of an additional hectares of old-growth forest lands in the heart of the Oak Ridges Moraine, the southern Ontario's most significant landforms. status_message_cleaned: The Little Brown Bat, also known as the Little Brown Myotis, is listed as endangered under the Government of Canada's Species at Risk Act. Once wide-ranging and numerous, populations of these bats have declined steeply in recent years due to habitat loss, human disturbance of colonies, and white-nose syndrome, in which a fungus grows on the bat’s skin causing death. Environment and Climate Change Canada is partnering with Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect hectares of wildlife habitat in central Saskatchewan. This area is home to the Little Brown Bat as well as many other species at risk, including the Northern Long-Eared Bat and Canada Warbler.

status_message_cleaned: How is hail formed? It’s when updrafts in thunderclouds carry raindrops upward into extremely cold areas of the atmosphere, where they freeze and merge into lumps of ice. When the lumps become too heavy to be supported by the updraft, they fall to the ground at speeds of up to km/h or more. Interesting!

status_message_cleaned: August marked the th anniversary of the Dr. Neil Trivett Global Atmosphere Watch Observatory, located in Alert, Nunavut. It is more commonly known as the Alert Research Laboratory. The lab was constructed in to focus on long-term monitoring of background concentrations of trace gases, aerosols and organic pollutants. It is the most northern permanently inhabited research station in the world and less than ,000 km from the North Pole. Happy th!

status_message_cleaned: Outdoor enthusiasts have long been drawn to the Montagnes Vertes region of southern Quebec. Its hiking trails and ski slopes offer unmatched views of the old-growth forest wilderness. The area is also home to wide-ranging mammals, including moose, bobcats, black bears and fishers, as well as a number of species at risk such as the Bicknell’s Thrush and Canada Warbler. Environment and Climate Change Canada is working with the Nature Conservancy of Canada and local donors to greatly eand the Montagnes Vertes nature reserve around Mont Sutton to protect important wildlife habitat while continuing public access to the area’s natural beauty.

status_message_cleaned: Environment and Climate Change Canada is pleased to announce the th Ecological Gift in Ontario. Sandra Nelles generously donated a conservation easement over hectares of her rural residential property to the Oak Ridges Moraine Land Trust that was certified through the Ecological Gifts Program. The conservation easement was specifically designed for her property and included protection zones to preserve forested areas that contain Butternut—a species of tree endangered in Canada—and zones for continued farming. Ms. Nelles retains ownership of the property, while restricting future development and protecting the ecological features of the land.

status_message_cleaned: The Bartholomew River, which runs through the Miramichi region of New Brunswick, has long been a favourite destination for anglers. The wild Atlantic salmon that ply its waters support recreational fisheries and are an important food source for Indigenous communities. Environment and Climate Change Canada is partnering with the Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect the Bartholomew River and restore and enhance this important salmon habitat. Protecting the river and its adjacent forestland from future development will improve water quality and help to regulate the water temperature of the river, improving fish health.

status_message_cleaned: Canada’s forests play an essential role in sustaining the quantity and quality of our water supply. They reduce soil erosion, regulate groundwater levels and naturally filter out pollutants. Environment and Climate Change Canada is proud to work with the Nature Conservancy of Canada to eand the preservation of forested lands around Saint-Hippolyte, Quebec. status_message_cleaned: Attention, wildlife enthusiasts! Did you know that from mid-April until the end of May, an Environment and Climate Change Canada team will be taking to the skies to count the ducks and geese breeding in and around the water bodies in the St. Lawrence Lowlands? Travelling by helicopter, the observers will identify and count all the species present, including Mallards, American Black Ducks and Wood Ducks. Back in the office, the team will compile the data, which will be used to provide a portrait of Quebec’s waterfowl populations.

status_message_cleaned: In , the Musquash Estuary on the Bay of Fundy was designated New Brunswick's only federal Marine Protected Area. Now, on the tenth anniversary of its designation, the Government of Canada is pleased to partner with the Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect an additional hectares of this ecologically-sensitive wetlands habitat. The Musquash Estuary is also a key point on the Atlantic Flyway, a major bird migration route. The location, remoteness and position of the Estuary wetlands provide excellent habitat for migratory sea ducks, particularly black scoter and white-winged scoter. Uc2

status_message_cleaned: The cedar is a naturally rare species of tree in Nova Scotia and one that has been made even scarcer due to human activity. It is listed as ‘vulnerable’ under the province’s Endangered Species Act. Environment and Climate Change Canada is proud to partner with Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect one of the largest cedar forests in the province and one of only a handful in northern Nova Scotia. This forested area, located near the Pugwash River in Cumberland County, was secured through a private donation made possible through the Government of Canada's Ecological Gifts Program.

status_message_cleaned: Did you know the Lobster Bay area near Yarmouth, N.S., is the only place in Canada where you can find the Eastern Baccharis, a rare species of shrub? This species, also called the Groundseltree, is a member of the Atlantic Coastal Plains Flora, a group of flowering plants, shrubs and herbs, many of which are legally listed under the Species at Risk Act. In fact, only mature Eastern Baccharis plants exist today. Environment and Climate Change Canada is working with the Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect hectares of marshland on Roberts Island in Lobster Bay. These lands are not only home to the Eastern Baccharis, but also provide important habitat for water birds, including the black duck, long-tailed duck and green-winged teal.

status_message_cleaned: Help conserve turtle species at risk in Canada! Canada’s Species at Risk Act seeks to protect critical habitat from being destroyed. Areas of critical habitat are proposed in the recovery strategies for four species of turtles found in Ontario: Blanding's Turtle, Eastern Musk Turtle, Spiny Softshell and Spotted Turtle. These areas of critical habitat may occur on or near your property. It may include lakes, rivers, streams and wetlands where the turtles are found, as well as adjacent meadows and forests. You are invited to comment on the proposed recovery documents. 9

status_message_cleaned: If you are a fisher, farmer or even an outdoors enthusiast, wetlands play a major role in your life. Wetlands support Canadians economically, socially and environmentally. Further, marshes, swamps, bogs, fens and shallow waters host a huge variety of life, protect our coastlines, act as natural sponges against flooding, and store carbon that helps regulate climate change. Let’s celebrate the importance of wetlands together. Happy World Wetlands Day! The Government of Canada is working with partner funding programs such as the National Wetland Conservation Fund to support projects that restore and enhance wetlands.

status_message_cleaned: Ever heard of the Hooded Merganser? It’s just one of the species whose habitat will be protected on the Columbia Valley’s oldest working cattle ranch. In partnership with the Nature Conservancy of Canada and others, hectares of grasslands is now protected as part of the Government of Canada’s Natural Areas Conservation Program. Wetlands on the property also support foraging and breeding habitat for several other waterfowl species, including Barrow’s Goldeneye, Mallard and Ruddy Duck. status_message_cleaned: Does Chignecto Isthmus ring a bell? It’s a narrow strip of land that joins mainland Nova Scotia to New Brunswick and the rest of Canada. It’s also an important habitat for moose, lynx, bobcat and various other species and is an important stopover for migrating waterfowl. In partnership with the Nature Conservancy of Canada and other partners, an additional hectares of the Moose Sex Corridor is now protected as part of the Government of Canada’s Natural Areas Conservation Program, totaling ,227 hectares of protected land.
